title-group.article-title: Freshwater macroinvertebrates of Lord Howe Island

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Freshwater macroinvertebrates of Lord Howe Island
Ivor Growns a *, Darren Ryder a , Tsuyoshi Kobayashi b and Adriana García c

a Environmental and Rural Sciences, University of New England , Armidale, NSW, Australia ; b Department of Premier and Cabinet, Science Division, Office of Environment and Heritage NSW, Sydney South NSW, Australia ; c School of Earth and Environmental Sciences, University of Wollongong, NSW, Australia
( Received 1 November 2013 ; accepted 17 June 2014 ; first published online 13 August 2014 )

Studies on freshwater invertebrate fauna on islands are rare but a few suggest species richness can be high. A survey of the freshwater invertebrates of Lord Howe Island (LHI) yielded 38 taxa, bringing the total recorded from LHI to 54. The majority of the taxa from the survey were from the Insecta , with 15 Diptera (true flies), five hemipterans (true bugs) and five trichopterans (caddisflies). Two species of gastropods, three mites and eight other arthropods were also found. The total number of taxa on LHI, although smaller than other islands, is the highest per unit area ever recorded (3.9 taxa per km 2 ). High levels of endemism were recorded for most taxonomic groups and two previously undescribed chironomid species were found. However, further taxonomic and genetic work is necessary in order to assess true levels of endemism by investigating the genetic similarities and differences of these taxa with nearby islands.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Keywords: macroinvertebrate; biodiversity; endemism; Australia

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fresh water makes up only 0.01% (v/v) of the world’ s water and approximately 0.8% of the Earth’ s surface area, yet this tiny fraction of global water supports at least 100,000 species out of approximately 1.8 million, almost 6% of all described species ( ). Comprehensive data on the diversity of most invertebrate groups in tropical and sub-tropical freshwaters do not exist, but high levels of local endemism and species richness seem typical of several major groups, including decapod crustaceans, molluscs and aquatic insects such as caddisflies and mayflies ( , ; ; ). In addition, among assemblages that evolved in isolated lakes on islands, low gene flow and local radiation can lead to considerable inter-drainage variation in biodiversity and high levels of endemism (e.g. ; ). Studies on the freshwater aquatic invertebrate fauna on islands are rare but the few that have been published suggest a large number of species can exist. For example, found 182 taxa (including microinvertebrates) in a tropical stream on Bougainville Island. recorded 328 taxa from 14 Caribbean islands. However, the macroinvertebrate fauna on remote oceanic islands such as LHI may not be as species rich (Brooks et al. online). suggested that aquatic macroinvertebrate faunas on these islands are generally sparse compared with those islands adjacent to continents or within chains of islands, because of their oceanic origin, their small size and potentially greater frequency of climatic disturbances.

Lord Howe Island (LHI) is the eroded remains of a seven-million-year-old shield volcano in the Tasman Sea south-west Pacific Ocean, lying in between Australia ( 600 km to the west) and New Zealand ( 1400 km to the south-east) and 772 km from Norfolk Island to its north-east ( ). The island is about 10 km long and between 2.0 and 0.3 km wide with an area of approximately 14 km 2 . The north and south sections of the island have relatively intact forest and there are two volcanic mountains, Mount Lidgbird in the south ( 777 m elevation) and Mount Gower ( 875 m ) in the north ( ). It is one of a chain of islands that occurs on the western rim of the Lord Howe Rise shelf and extends from New Zealand to the west of New Caledonia . It is thought the undersea shelf separated from the Australian plate 60–80 million years ago to form a new crust in the deep Tasman Basin. The shelf is part of Zealandia, a microcontinent nearly half the size of Australia that gradually submerged after breaking away from the Gondwanan supercontinent ( ). The coastal margins surrounding LHI contain the southernmost coral reefs in the Pacific Ocean ( ).

Lord Howe Island has a biologically diverse native biota with a higher levels of endemism than other islands at this latitude (e.g. Norfolk and Raoul Islands; ). The island has a large number of taxa in common with Australia (129), New Caledonia (102), New Zealand (75) and Norfolk Island (66), suggesting these have been dominant pathways for dispersal and colonization ( ). For example, Anguilla reinhardtii , the long-finned eel endemic to eastern Australia , New Caledonia , Norfolk Island , and Lord Howe Island was recently described in rivers of northern New Zealand ( ), highlighting the dispersal capacity of many ‘freshwater’ taxa. Prior to the British Naval discovery of the island in 1788 ( ), there were 13 endemic species of terrestrial avifauna, and two terrestrial reptiles (a skink, Pseudemoia lichenigera and a gecko, Christinus guentheri ; ). The native flora consists of 241 species, of which 44% are endemic ( ). Endemism at the generic level includes the palms ( Howea , Hedyscepe and Lepidorrhachis ), the tree Negria , the terrestrial leech Quantenobdella howensis , three annelid genera ( Paraplutellus , Pericryptodrilus and Eastoniella ), an isopod Stigmops , a hemipteran bug Howeria and a cricket Howeta ( Hutton et al. 2007 ) .

Published lists of invertebrate taxa show that over 50% are of endemic species (e.g. ), but descriptions of only a few groups have been published and the earlier records are incomplete. For example, a study on the dispersal of the genus Paratya in the south Pacific found that individuals from LHI were most closely related to Norfolk Island , and the two islands then formed a sister relationship with New Caledonia ( ). The freshwater fauna of LHI has also been subject to limited taxonomic studies (e.g. ; ); however, to date there has been no systematic survey of its freshwater invertebrate fauna. Our objective was to establish the first aquatic invertebrate survey of LHI by sampling the assemblages in most of its standing and running waters. We discuss the number and types of the taxa found in comparison to other islands, potential colonization sources and levels of endemism on LHI .
Climate

Lord Howe Island has a subtropical climate with warm summers (mean maximum temperature of approximately 25°C) and cool winters (mean maximum temperature of approximately 19°C). The island has reasonably high rainfall, with an annual average and median of about 1600 mm with rainfall erratic in summer and more or less uniform in winter. The driest months are November to February. There is a gradual transition from summer to winter conditions and vice versa ( ). Winds are frequent and salt-laden, being moderate easterlies in summer and fresh to strong westerlies in winter. July is the windiest month and the winter months are subject to frequent gales and strong winds. Storm events and occasional cyclonic activity also affect the island ( ).
Methods

Sampling was based on the methods described in and collections were made between 26 November and 2 December 2011 in three stream channels and five wetlands ( Figure 1 and Table 1 ). Animals from each site were collected using a 0.25 mm hand-held dip net with a 320 × 250 mm opening to target macroinvertebrate fauna. All habitat types , including running water, edges and leaf litter in stream channels and edges, macrophytes and open water in wetlands were sampled in a composite sample where present. The net contents were emptied into a large white sorting tray and spread out in a small amount of water to allow macroinvertebrate specimens to be picked out alive with fine forceps and pipettes. The aim of the picking was to collect as wide a range of macroinvertebrates as possible to maximize taxonomic richness with no more than 10 specimens of any taxon collected. The selection of only conspicuous or colourful specimens was deliberately avoided and efforts are made to obtain small and cryptic animals as well as larger ones. For each site, 100 animals were targeted; however, collection was terminated when this target could not be reached following one hour of picking. Since the specimens are selected while alive, small and encased animals were easily detected by their movements. All collected specimens were preserved immediately in 70% ethanol. Animals were identified to the lowest practicable taxonomic level possible using current taxonomic keys under dissecting and compound microscopes.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 38 invertebrate taxa were recorded ( Table 2 ). The majority of the taxa were from the class Insecta , with 15 taxa of Diptera (true flies), five hemipteran (true bugs) taxa and five trichopterans (caddisflies). In addition, two species of gastropods, three aquatic mites and eight other arthropods were found.

Twenty-six taxa were recorded from the streams and 12 from the wetlands. More taxa were collected from the individual streams compared to the wetlands, with an average of seven taxa. Only one taxon, the talitrid amphipod, Parorchestia gowerensi , was common to both streams and wetlands but was only recorded from two streams and one wetland. The remaining taxa were confined to either streams or channels.

Five taxa, including the chironomids Polypedilum S1 and Paramerina sp. nov. , the veliid Microvelia sp. , the hydropsychid Cheumatopsyche and the leptocerid Note: *The airport wetland is ephemeral and this was the approximate surface area at the time of sampling.

Symphitoneuria neboissi were found in all three streams. Three taxa including the notonectid Anisops sp. , the cyclopoid Australocyclops australis and the cyprididae Sarcypridopsis cf. aculeata were found in all wetlands.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We recorded 38 invertebrate taxa from the freshwater bodies present on Lord Howe Island. This brings the total number of freshwater taxa recorded on LHI to 54, as recorded an additional eight species of caddisflies, an additional seven species of snails, and one species of damselfly, Ischnura aurora , has been found (Ceaira Cottle, pers. comm.). We expect that more species of freshwater invertebrate fauna will be recorded on LHI following additional research and surveys, as well as further taxonomic work. For example, several of the currently identified taxa may actually represent more than one species per taxon. The potential discovery of new species is highlighted by the finding of the Tricopteran genus Tascohorema in the Hydrobiosidae , despite the collection of caddisflies on LHI over several years by , and the discovery of two previously undescribed species of Chironomidae (Peter Cranston, pers. comm.) during this study. Our failure to collect the additional caddisfly and snails suggests that one survey may not be enough to provide a complete list of taxa for the island as the occurrence of some taxa may be seasonally variable and/or with patchy or isolated distributions.

In comparison with freshwater invertebrates recorded on other islands, the number of recorded taxa on LHI is low. However, when the area of LHI is taken into account (i.e. taxonomic density) the freshwater invertebrate fauna on LHI is diverse, with a density of ~3.9 taxa km − 2 compared with an average density of 0.3 taxa km − 2 ( n = 20, range: 0.01– 2.80 km − 2 ) estimated from other island studies ( Figure 2 and Table 3 ). However, direct comparisons between studies are challenging due to the various levels of taxonomy available, contrasting sampling methods and net sizes and different spatial and temporal sampling intensities. Nonetheless, patterns in richness and differences between assemblages observed between studies may reflect spatial turnover due to underlying environmental gradients (e.g. ; ).

also reported that LHI stands out among island faunas as having a relatively large number of snail taxa, considering the age, isolation and surface area of the island. suggested that an island’ s size is an important factor in determining its species richness and data available from the present study and others ( Table 3 ) demonstrate a significant relationship between island area and number of taxa ( Figure 2 ). also suggested the maximum elevation of an island is an important factor in determining the number of aquatic faunal species because islands with greater elevations will have a higher rainfall and therefore more diversified aquatic habitats. Lord Howe Island has two peaks greater than 700 m . It is possible that the island’ s topography determines its capacity to support such a relatively large number of taxa. It is intuitive to claim that the abundance and species richness of aquatic taxa might increase with an increase in the amount of habitats available ( ). There have been many studies that demonstrate, for example, relationships between surrogate estimates of habitat availability and the number of fish species (e.g. ; ; ). However, the use of surrogate measures of habitat size does not distinguish the related, but separate role of habitat diversity, complexity and disturbance, and this makes direct comparisons between separate studies and regions difficult .

Although direct comparisons may be difficult among studies, there are some invertebrate groups that are noticeably absent from LHI. No beetle ( Coleoptera ), mayfly (Ephemeroptera), or dragonfly ( Odonata , suborder Epiprocta ) taxa have been found yet, although these groups can represent 30%, 10% and 5% of taxa, respectively, in other areas of Australia ( ; ; ), and have been also recorded on other islands ( ; ). The absence of mayfly taxa may not be surprising because of the distance of LHI to any other landmass and mayflies are relatively small, generally are not strong fliers and the adults are short lived. In contrast, many dragonflies and beetle species are relatively long-lived and are strong fliers and so presumably would be able to disperse to remote islands such as LHI, evidenced by the presence of these families in Norfolk Island streams (e.g. ). However, the different climate, weather and habitat conditions may make it difficult for populations to persist, even if individuals of certain taxa reach the island. Brooks et al. (online) suggested that an absence of dragonfly taxa from the Falkland Islands may be related to the persistent strong winds that occur there. also noted that beetle taxa were rare in aquatic habitats in the Caribbean Islands but did not suggest why.

To become established and persist on an island, a species must first successfully disperse to that island in sufficient numbers to create a breeding population and have sufficient resources to maintain population dynamics. However, the mechanism by which the different taxa have come to LHI is likely to differ between them, depending on their dispersal abilities. suggested that there have been at least three separate invasions of hydrobiid snails to Lord Howe Island from eastern Australia or from islands to the north or New Caledonia . The method of transportation to the island was almost certainly by accidental external attachment to birds either directly, or more likely, by being caught up in mud. This method of accidental dispersal of freshwater snails is well known ( ). The wetland fauna observed on LHI may also have been brought by birds. and have documented zooplankton, chironomids, and possibly corixids, being transported by migratory birds (see also ); a common way of passive dispersal recorded for freshwater ostracods that produce resistant eggs when their habitat dries or ecological conditions become unsuitable for them ( ). The three species of aquatic mite found on LHI are also found on mainland Australia and suggested that mites are able to disperse widely at their larval stage via their insect hosts. suggested adult caddisflies may have been blown to Lord Howe Island by strong winds and that some species recorded are itinerant, having no permanent populations on the island. Another potential mechanism of transportation for flightless invertebrates that have life stages potentially tolerant of marine waters, such as shrimp, crabs and isopods, is rafting on debris carried by ocean currents ( ).

The dispersal ability of the different taxa is likely to affect the level of endemism within those groups. Taxa that do not easily disperse are more likely to become endemic to LHI. Three of the four malacostracan taxa, the majority of the tricopterans and the mollusc taxa recorded in this study are endemic to LHI. In contrast, the presence of the cyclopoid Australocyclops australis in wetlands is perhaps not surprising, as this species is widespread and common over most of Australia ( ). The species is an opportunistic, early colonizer of new habitats including temporary pools, farm dams and large man-made reservoirs where they establish true planktonic populations ( ). For other taxa, further taxonomic work is necessary in order to assess their levels of endemism. This highlights the potential for research into DNA sequencing to investigate the genetic similarities and differences of these taxa with those in nearby islands, including Australia and New Zealand (e.g. , ).

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: The Lord Howe Island Board is thanked for the use of the research facility during sampling. Hank Bower , Christo Haselden and Ian Hutton are thanked for providing logistical support. Peter Cranston , Cathy Cunningham , Jim Lowry , Chris Madden , Alison Wells and Buz Wilson are thanked for the identification of some invertebrates. This work was carried out under Scientific Collection Permit (P02/0021-7.0) issued under the Fisheries Management Act , 1994 and a Scientific Licence ( SL100061 ) under the National Parks & Wildlife Act , 1974. The coeditor, Dr Andrew Polaszek , Dr Tim Page and another anonymous referee are thanked for their useful comments on a draft manuscript .
